I. The need to track participants over a long period, which can be costly and time-consuming.
II. Changes in the environment over time may confound results.
III. Participant attrition over time.

But since the user didn't include the actual options, I need to infer based on common disadvantages of longitudinal studies. Let me think.

Longitudinal studies have several disadvantages. One is the high cost and time required to track participants over many years. Another is the potential for attrition, where participants drop out over time, leading to a smaller sample size and possible bias. Also, there's the issue of cohort effects, where the specific group being studied might change over time, making it hard to generalize. Another is that some variables might change over time due to external factors, making it difficult to isolate the effects of the variables being studied.

So if the options were I (cost and time), II (environmental changes), III (attrition), then the answer would be D (I and II only) or something else. Wait, but the user's answer was (A) I only. II. Possible changes in the environment over time
III. Difficulty in maintaining participant interest

II. Environmental changes
III. Confounding variables
